questions.text: A 15-year-old male child presents with a right-sided nasal mass and profuse epistaxis with hyponasality of voice, findings suggestive of conductive hearing loss, and cheek swelling. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario, the most probable diagnosis is Angiofibroma

Angiofibroma

  • The most common benign tumor of the nasopharynx
  • Arises from the sphenopalatine foramen
  • Exclusive in adolescent males

Clinical features

  • Presents with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction, hyponasality( Rhinolalia clausa)
  • On examination, a red and fleshy mass was seen in the nasal cavity
  • As Eustachian tube obstruction occurs, serous otitis media can occur, and the patient can present with conductive type hearing loss

The tumor can spread into

  • Laterally- pterygopalatine fossa, causing pressure over the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, causing it to bow anteriorly, called the Holman Miller sign or Antral sign, seen in contrast CT
  • Orbit- through the inferior orbital fissure, causing proptosis, diplopia, with involvement of II, III, IV, and VI cranial nerves, depending on the extent of the tumor
  • Infratemporal fossa- through the pterygomaxillary fissure, and appears as cheek swelling
  • Intracranial extension can occur

Nasal bridge broadening, proptosis, and cheek swelling give rise to frog face deformity

Explanation of other options

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (option A): More common in older individuals, often adults >40. Symptoms may include nasal obstruction, epistaxis, neck nodes, and conductive hearing loss. Cheek swelling is not a typical feature. Much less common in adolescents.

Inverted papilloma (option B): Usually seen in middle-aged adults. Originates from the lateral nasal wall. May cause nasal obstruction and epistaxis, but usually not profuse. Cheek swelling and hearing loss are not common. It has malignant potential, but doesn't present this dramatically in a teenager.

Thornwaldt's disease (option C): A benign midline nasopharyngeal cyst, usually asymptomatic or causes postnasal drip. May cause halitosis or nasal obstruction, rarely. Not associated with epistaxis, hearing loss, or cheek swelling.

questions.text: A 52-year-old adult patient presenting with right-sided hearing loss with no history of ear discharge, pain, or upper respiratory infection, has been subjected to audiological investigations and was found to have a type B tympanogram. What will be the priority in further management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In an adult, unilateral conductive hearing loss with a Type B tympanogram in the absence of active infection, ear discharge, or upper respiratory symptoms is highly suspicious for nasopharyngeal pathology, most notably nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC).
  • A Type B tympanogram suggests a middle ear effusion, which in adults should raise concern for Eustachian tube obstruction. When unilateral and painless, especially in older adults, NPC must be ruled out, as it can compress or infiltrate the Eustachian tube.
  • Therefore, the next priority is to perform a nasopharyngoscopy to directly visualize the nasopharynx and obtain a biopsy of any suspicious lesion for histopathological diagnosis.

Investigations in NPC for diagnosis:

  • Nasopharyngoscopy (Diagnostic Nasal Endoscopy)
    • Essential for direct visualization of the nasopharynx
    • Common findings:
      • Exophytic mass in the fossa of Rosenmuller (most common site)
      • Mucosal irregularity, ulceration, or bleeding
  • Biopsy
    • Confirms diagnosis (definitive)
    • Taken from the mass under endoscopic guidance
    • Sent for histopathological examination (usually squamous cell carcinoma or undifferentiated carcinoma)
  • Audiological Evaluation
    • Pure tone audiometry (PTA): Shows conductive hearing loss on the affected side
    • Tympanometry: Shows Type B tympanogram (indicative of middle ear effusion)
    • Helps in evaluating Eustachian tube dysfunction
  • Imaging
    • Contrast-enhanced CT scan or MRI of the head and neck:
      • Assesses the extent of local invasion
      • Detects skull base erosion, parapharyngeal spread, or intracranial extension
    • MRI is more sensitive for soft tissue and cranial nerve involvement

Explanation of Other Options:

Conservative management (Option B): Not appropriate, conservative watchful waiting is acceptable in children, but not in adults without an obvious benign cause.

Myringotomy and grommet insertion( Option C): Inappropriate without ruling out nasopharyngeal malignancy. Treating symptomatically without addressing the underlying cause (possible NPC) is a mistake.

Antibiotic and decongestant therapy (Option D): This may be appropriate in cases of infection or allergy in younger patients. In this adult with a unilateral Type B tympanogram, it risks delaying cancer diagnosis.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with recurrent profuse epistaxis and progressive right-sided nasal obstruction. On examination, a reddish mass is seen in the nasopharynx. CECT reveals a well-enhancing mass arising near the sphenopalatine foramen, extending into the nasopharynx, nasal cavity, and occupying the entire pterygopalatine fossa, with Holman-Miller sign. There is no intracranial or orbital extension. What is the most likely stage of the tumor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the clinical scenario, the most probable diagnosis would be Angiofibroma( JNA), and the stage according to Radkowski staging is Stage IIB

Radkowski's staging of Angiofibroma

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with progressive unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of profuse epistaxis. On anterior rhinoscopy, a reddish polypoidal mass is seen in the nasopharynx that bleeds on touch. What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This presentation is highly suggestive of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA), a vascular tumor seen almost exclusively in adolescent males. The investigation of choice for this condition is CECT scan with angiography.

The investigation of choice is:

  • CECT scan: Defines the extent of the tumor, involvement of sinuses, pterygopalatine fossa, orbit, etc. Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, often called antral sign or Holman-Miller sign, is pathognomonic of angiofibroma.
  • Angiography: Confirms the vascular nature, helps in identifying feeding vessels, and is essential if preoperative embolization is planned. Embolization of vessels can be done at this time to decrease bleeding during the operation. Feeders from only the external carotid system can be embolized. Resection of the tumour should not be delayed beyond 24-48 hr of embolization to avoid revascularization from the contralateral side.

Other investigation:

  • Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is complementary to CT scans and shows any soft tissue extensions present intracranially in the infratemporal fossa or the orbit.

Explanation of Other Options:

CECT scan (Option A): Good, but angiography is also needed to plan management and avoid bleeding.

CT scan (Option B)(plain): Lacks vascular detail; insufficient for surgical planning in a vascular tumor.

Biopsy (Option C): Never done without imaging in a suspected angiofibroma - high risk of life-threatening bleeding. Contraindicated

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy diagnosed with juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is scheduled for surgical resection. Which of the following is not routinely recommended as part of preoperative or intraoperative management to reduce bleeding or facilitate surgical excision?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Preoperative debulking of the tumor is not recommended in JNA

  • Angiofibroma is a highly vascular tumor, and its blood vessels lack elastic tissue and muscle fibres and hence cannot contract.
  • So, pre-operative debulking of tumors results in massive hemorrhage.
  • The tumor should be removed completely in one planned surgery, often with embolization.
  • Partial removal (debulking) increases the risk of uncontrolled bleeding and recurrence.

Explanation of Other Options:

Preoperative Embolization (Option A): Gold standard for minimizing blood loss during JNA surgery. Usually done 24-48 hours before surgery. Embolizes feeding vessels (commonly branches of the internal maxillary artery). It can reduce intraoperative bleeding by up to 85%.

Preoperative Flutamide (Option B): Flutamide is a non-steroidal anti-androgen. Since JNA is hormonally influenced, anti-androgen therapy may help shrink the tumor or reduce vascularity. Sometimes used when embolization is not feasible or to supplement embolization. More commonly used in non-surgical candidates or large tumors awaiting surgery.

Preoperative Estrogen (Option C): Historically used due to the hormone-sensitivity of JNA, especially diethylstilbestrol (DES). Works by causing regression of vascular components. Not a first-line option today due to side effects, but still valid in non-surgical or recurrent cases where embolization is not an option.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man of Southeast Asian origin presents with progressive nasal obstruction, intermittent epistaxis, and right-sided conductive hearing loss. Endoscopic biopsy of a nasopharyngeal mass reveals an undifferentiated non-keratinizing carcinoma. Serology shows elevated IgA titers against viral capsid antigen. Which of the following viruses is most strongly implicated in the pathogenesis of this tumor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is strongly associated with non-keratinizing undifferentiated nasopharyngeal carcinoma, especially in endemic regions like Southern China, Hong Kong, and Southeast Asia.

Specific viral markers are being developed to screen people in high-incidence areas.

EB virus has two important antigens:

  • Viral capsid antigen(VCA)- IgA antibodies of VCA are more sensitive for nasopharyngeal cancer.
  • Early antigen(EA)- IgA antibodies of EA are highly specific for nasopharyngeal cancer.

Other factors responsible for NPC:

  • Genetics- Chinese have a higher susceptibility to nasopharyngeal cancer
  • Environmental- Air pollution, tobacco, nitrosamines from dry salted fish, polycyclic hydrocarbons

Cancers Associated with EBV Infection:

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Burkitt lymphoma (especially endemic/African type)
  • Hodgkin lymphoma (especially the mixed cellularity type)
  • Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD)
  • Primary CNS lymphoma (especially in HIV/AIDS patients)
  • Gastric carcinoma (EBV-associated subtype)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia (pre-malignant, seen in immunocompromised patients)
  • Infectious mononucleosis (non-malignant but EBV-related)

Explanation of Other Options:

HPV (Option A): HPV is not the primary virus implicated in nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC). It is strongly associated with oropharyngeal cancers, particularly those involving the Tonsils and the Base of the tongue. HPV-positive oropharyngeal cancers have distinct epidemiology and prognosis. Therefore, while HPV is oncogenic, it does not play a major role in the pathogenesis of NPC, especially the non-keratinizing, undifferentiated type, which is EBV-associated.

HSV (Option C): HSV (especially HSV-1) is linked to mucocutaneous infections Oral herpes (cold sores) and Genital herpes. It has no established etiological link with NPC. HSV is not oncogenic in the same way as EBV or HPV.

HCV (Option D): HCV primarily affects the liver, not the nasopharynx. It is associated with Hepatocellular carcinoma and Certain lymphomas (e.g., marginal zone lymphoma). HCV does not play a role in the development of NPC.

Weber Fergusson's transmaxillary approach is ideal for the mass limited to the nose & nasopharynx
The tumor is seen 24 times more commonly in patients with adenomatous polyposis of the colon
C-myc is a proto-oncogene found in large tumors

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with recurrent epistaxis and progressive nasal obstruction. A contrast-enhanced CT scan reveals a vascular mass in the nasopharynx extending into the nasal cavity. All of the following statements about the condition are true except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Based on the clinical scenario, the most probable condition is JNA
  • For tumors limited to the nose and nasopharynx, the endoscopic endonasal approach is now preferred, especially for Radkowski Stage I/II lesions.
  • The Weber-Fergusson approach is more invasive and reserved for more extensive lesions.
  • Tumours confined to the nasopharynx can be approached through a transnasal endoscopic approach or Wilson's transpalatal approach.

Explanation of Options:

The nidus of fibrovascular tissue for the origin of angiofibroma is due to incomplete regression of the first branchial artery(Option A): The tumor arises near the sphenopalatine foramen, where remnants of the first branchial artery may persist. These vascular remnants are believed to form the fibrovascular core of the tumor

The tumor is seen 24 times more commonly in patients with adenomatous polyposis of the colon(Option C): JNA is associated with Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP). FAP patients have a 24-fold increased risk of developing JNA due to APC gene mutations. If JNA is found in a young male with a family history of colon cancer, consider screening for FAP

C-myc is a proto-oncogene found in large angiofibromas(Option D): The c-myc oncogene, known for regulating cell proliferation, has been found overexpressed in large or aggressive JNAs. This may correlate with the size and recurrence potential of the tumor. While JNA is histologically benign, its behavior can be aggressive, and c-myc involvement may partly explain that.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with nasal obstruction, intermittent epistaxis, and right-sided hearing loss for 3 months. Nasal endoscopy reveals a mass in the fossa of Rosenmller. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the given clinical scenario, the most probable diagnosis is nasopharyngeal carcinoma

  • As the tumor is confined to the nasopharynx and regional lymph node, the treatment of choice would be Chemoradiation
  • Concurrent chemoradiotherapy (CCRT) is the treatment of choice, especially for Stage II and above, where there is nodal involvement or locally advanced disease.

Treatment modalities in NPC

  • Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for stage I and is combined with chemotherapy beyond stage II. External beam radiation of 6000- 7000 cGy can be delivered
  • Chemotherapy improves locoregional control and reduces distant metastasis. Cisplatin-based chemotherapy is the most commonly used regimen with RT.

Key takeaway: The cure rate doubles when chemotherapy is combined with radiotherapy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Surgical excision with neck dissection(Option A): NPC is not treated surgically due to its deep location and excellent response to radiation.

Chemotherapy(Option B): Not effective as monotherapy; radiation is essential.

Radiotherapy(Option C): Used only for very early-stage disease (T1N0), which is rare at presentation. This case suggests more extensive disease (mass + symptoms), so chemoradiation is required.

questions.text: Which of the following is not premalignant?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Median rhomboid glossitis is described as a chronic erythematous candidiasis of the dorsum of the tongue, with no malignant potential.

Etiology (Causes):

  • Candida albicans (the most common causative agent)
  • Risk factors:
    • Poorly fitting dentures (especially upper dentures)
    • Continuous denture wear (especially overnight)
    • Poor oral hygiene
    • Xerostomia (dry mouth)
    • Smoking
    • Systemic immunosuppression (e.g., diabetes, HIV)
    • Prolonged use of antibiotics or corticosteroids

Clinical Features:

  • Dull red erythematous area under the denture-bearing surface, especially the palate (common site).
  • May be asymptomatic or present with a burning sensation or discomfort.
  • The surface may appear smooth and atrophic.
  • No white curd-like plaques, unlike acute pseudomembranous candidiasis.
  • May be associated with angular cheilitis or median rhomboid glossitis.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical appearance
  • Denture history
  • Smear or swab for KOH mount or PAS stain (to detect fungal hyphae)
  • Culture on Sabouraud's agar (if needed)
  • Rule out other causes of palatal erythema (e.g., trauma, allergy)

Treatment:

  • Topical antifungal therapy:
    • Nystatin oral suspension (100,000 units/mL): rinse 4-5 times/day
    • Clotrimazole troches or miconazole oral gel
  • Systemic antifungals (in resistant or immunocompromised cases):
    • Fluconazole 50-100 mg once daily for 7-14 days
  • Denture hygiene and modifications:
    • Remove dentures at night
    • Clean dentures daily and soak in chlorhexidine or antifungal solutions
    • Denture relining or replacement if poorly fitting
  • Treat associated conditions:
    • Angular cheilitis: topical antifungal ± steroid
    • Address systemic risk factors (e.g., diabetes)

Explanation of Other Options:

Oral Submucous Fibrosis (Option A): It is a chronic, progressive, scarring disease of the oral mucosa characterized by juxta-epithelial inflammatory reaction and progressive fibrosis of the submucosal tissues, leading to stiffness of the oral mucosa and restricted mouth opening. It is considered a premalignant condition predominantly caused by areca nut chewing.

Oral Lichen Planus (Option B): It is a chronic mucocutaneous inflammatory disease of unknown etiology characterized by white, lacy, reticular lesions on the oral mucosa, often accompanied by erythematous and erosive areas. It is considered a potentially premalignant disorder with immune-mediated pathogenesis.

Erythroplakia (Option C): It is defined as a bright red, velvety, patch-like lesion on the oral mucosa that cannot be clinically or pathologically characterized as any other condition. It is a highly premalignant lesion with a significant risk of progression to invasive carcinoma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of unilateral nasal obstruction and progressive hearing loss in the left ear( conductive type). He also complains of persistent dull pain around the left ear and nasal regurgitation while drinking water. What is the name of this clinical constellation of findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario shows unilateral conductive hearing loss, neuralgia, and palatal palsy, which is Trotter's Triad seen in Nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Trotter's triad is a feature of Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presenting with (mnemonic- NPC)

  • Temporoparietal neuralgia (due to Vth nerve involvement) presents with facial pain
  • Palatal palsy (due to Xth nerve involvement), presents with dysarthria and dysphagia
  • Unilateral conductive hearing loss(due to serous otitis media due to Eustachian tube blockage).

Explanation of Other Options:

Samter's Triad (Option A): Asthma, Nasal polyps, Aspirin sensitivity

Gradenigo's Triad (Option B): Otorrhea (chronic otitis media), Pain over the face (CN V involvement), Lateral rectus palsy (CN VI)- due to petrositis

Beck's Triad (Option D): Raised JVP, which is classic for cardiac tamponade

choices.text: Preoperative embolization followed by combined open and endoscopic excision
Endoscopic biopsy followed by neoadjuvant chemotherapy

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with recurrent epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and visual disturbances. Imaging reveals a large vascular mass arising from the nasopharynx with intracranial extension, involving the cavernous sinus and encasing the internal carotid artery. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario, the most probable diagnosis is JNA with intracranial extension, which is unresectable, so the most appropriate next step in management is Intensity-modulated radiotherapy (IMRT)

Radiotherapy:

  • Radiotherapy is the primary stand-alone mode of treatment, thus avoiding surgery.
  • A dose of 3000 to 3500 cGy in 15-18 fractions is delivered in 3- 3.5 weeks. Response is not immediate tumor regresses slowly in about a year, sometimes even up to 3 years
  • Another indication of radiotherapy is recurrent angiofibroma
  • Risks of radiation in young include:
    • Atrophic rhinitis
    • Suppression of growth centres of the bone
    • Development of angiosarcoma in later

Explanation of Other Options:

Preoperative embolization followed by combined open and endoscopic excision(Option A): Preoperative embolization is only indicated when surgical resection is planned. In this case, the tumor is unresectable due to involvement of critical structures (e.g., cavernous sinus, ICA). Surgery here carries high morbidity and is not first-line.

Endoscopic biopsy followed by neoadjuvant chemotherapy(Option C): Biopsy is contraindicated in JNA due to the high vascularity, which can cause a life-threatening hemorrhage. Chemotherapy is not standard first-line and is reserved for select, recurrent, or metastatic cases. Doxorubicin, vincristine, and dacarbazine have been used in combination.

Hormonal therapy (Option D): Hormonal therapy (e.g., anti-androgens) has a historical use but is not recommended. Diethylstilbestrol and flutamide( an androgen blocker) have been used to arrest the growth of the tumour. Largely replaced by radiotherapy in advanced cases.
